Article
Full-text available

Biomimetic design and fabrication of tissue engineered scaffolds using computer aided tissue enginee...

[...]
 Binil Starly
The field of tissue engineering brings together the multidisciplinary research of life sciences and engineering to seek man-made substitutes for the regeneration of damaged tissue or organs. A key component in tissue engineering is the use of porous scaffolds to guide cells for attachment, proliferation and differentiation in the tissue regenerative process. Upon satisfactory in-vitro culture, ... [Show full abstract] this engineered living scaffold is implanted into the regeneration site of the patient to function as the tissue substitute. Conventional processing techniques for the fabrication of scaffolds often encounter difficulties in the precise control of the internal architecture, interconnectivity and distribution of pores within the scaffold. These challenges, along with the advances in biology, medicine, and information technology for tissue engineering applications, have led to the development of a new field of Computer Aided Tissue Engineering (CATE). CATE enables a systematic application of computer-aided technologies, i.e., computer-aided design (CAD), image processing, computer-aided manufacturing (CAM), and solid freeform fabrication (SFF) for modeling, designing, simulation, and manufacturing of biological tissue and organ substitutes. Through the use of CATE, the design of intricate three dimensional architecture of scaffold can be realized and these scaffolds can be fabricated with reproducible accuracy to assist biologists in studying complex tissue engineering problems. This thesis reports a research addressing some of the challenges in applying the CATE approach for the biomimetic design and freeform fabrication of tissue scaffolds. The major research accomplishments reported in this thesis include: a) The development of a BioCAD modeling technique for the design and representation of patient specific 3D tissue models based on non-invasive medical image data. b) The development of a biomimetic design approach for design of load bearing tissue scaffold subject to multiple biophysical, geometrical and manufacturing requirements. This includes the design of the unit cell micro-architecture based on tissue morphologies, unit cell characterization and evaluation of the mechanical and transport properties, and the use of unit cells as building block to design anatomic tissue scaffold replacements. c) The development of a CAD based path planning procedure through a direct slicing algorithm which can convert a neutral ISO (International Standards Organization) standardized STEP (Standard for the Exchange of Product Data) formatted NURBS (Non-Uniform Rational B-Spline) geometric representation to a tool path instruction set for layered freeform fabrication. d) The development of a novel Internal Architecture Design (IAD) approach for the mapping of characteristic patterns of the unit cell micro-architectures designed within the 3D scaffold. This design approach is implemented into a process algorithm that converts these 2D patterns to tool path datasets for the 3DPTM (threedimensional printing) and extrusion based freeform fabrication. CATE enables many novel approaches in modeling, design, and fabrication of complex tissue substitutes with enhanced functionality for research in patient specific implant analysis and simulation, image guided surgical planning and scaffold guided tissue engineering. The research will also enable cell biologists and engineers to expand their scope of research and study in the field of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

Computer-Aided Virtual Screening and In Vitro Validation of Biomimetic Tyrosinase Inhibitory Peptide...
February 2023 · International Journal of Molecular Sciences
Sasikarn Kongsompong
 Teerasak E-kobon
Weerasak Taengphan
[...]
 Pramote Chumnanpuen
Hyperpigmentation is a medical and cosmetic problem caused by an excess accumulation of melanin or the overexpression of the enzyme tyrosinase, leading to several skin disorders, i.e., freckles, melasma, and skin cancer. Tyrosinase is a key enzyme in melanogenesis and thus a target for reducing melanin production. Although abalone is a good source of bioactive peptides that have been used for ... [Show full abstract] several properties including depigmentation, the available information on the anti-tyrosinase property of abalone peptides remains insufficient. This study investigated the anti-tyrosinase properties of Haliotis diversicolor tyrosinase inhibitory peptides (hdTIPs) based on mushroom tyrosinase, cellular tyrosinase, and melanin content assays. The binding conformation between peptides and tyrosinase was also examined by molecular docking and dynamics study. KNN1 showed a high potent inhibitory effect on mushroom tyrosinase with an IC50 of 70.83 μM. Moreover, our selected hdTIPs could inhibit melanin production through the reductions in tyrosinase activity and reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels by enhancing the antioxidative enzymes. RF1 showed the highest activity on both cellular tyrosinase inhibition and ROS reduction. leading to the lower melanin content in B16F10 murine melanoma cells. Accordingly, it can be assumed that our selected peptides exhibited high potential in medical cosmetology applications.

Biomimetic construction of the knee joint by laser scanning and computer-aided design/computer-aided...
July 2009 · Journal of Clinical Rehabilitative Tissue Engineering Research
[...]
G.-Q. Shi
The knee joint has complex structure and higher motor function requirements. After replacement, the wounded limb should be weight bearing and can do flexing or whirling activities with good stability. The necessary prerequisite is that the shape of the artificial knee joint must match human body. It can move coordinately with the surrounding parenchyma only when the shape is accuracy. So the ... [Show full abstract] design and manufacture of knee joint false body must be accuracy. In this article, the author makes use of three-dimensional laser scanning and computer-aid design technology to scan on the knee joint, and then deal with the output cloud data. Making use of project software Geomagic and Unigraphics to carry out the reconstruction and simulation processing of three-dimensional full-scale mock-up can obtain the very precise knee joint three-dimensional model and the numerical control processing program, which has provided one practical and feasible method for the fast precise designing and digitized manufacturing of individual phantom in clinical medicine.

<h3 class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit publication-recommendation-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare gtm-recommendation-item-link" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/publication/28674519_Biomimetic_design_and_fabrication_of_tissue_engineered_scaffolds_using_computer_aided_tissue_engineering" target="_blank">Biomimetic design and fabrication of tissue engineered scaffolds using computer aided tissue enginee...</a></h3>
<div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500"><span></span></div>
<ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-auto"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item">[...]</li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/390612802129921-1470140757907_Q64/Binil-Starly.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Binil Starly"></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Binil-Starly" type="button" target="_blank">Binil Starly</a></span></span></li>
</ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">The field of tissue engineering brings together the multidisciplinary research of life sciences and engineering to seek man-made substitutes for the regeneration of damaged tissue or organs. A key component in tissue engineering is the use of porous scaffolds to guide cells for attachment, proliferation and differentiation in the tissue regenerative process. Upon satisfactory in-vitro culture, <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdc610483","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdc610483"> this engineered living scaffold is implanted into the regeneration site of the patient to function as the tissue substitute. Conventional processing techniques for the fabrication of scaffolds often encounter difficulties in the precise control of the internal architecture, interconnectivity and distribution of pores within the scaffold. These challenges, along with the advances in biology, medicine, and information technology for tissue engineering applications, have led to the development of a new field of Computer Aided Tissue Engineering (CATE). CATE enables a systematic application of computer-aided technologies, i.e., computer-aided design (CAD), image processing, computer-aided manufacturing (CAM), and solid freeform fabrication (SFF) for modeling, designing, simulation, and manufacturing of biological tissue and organ substitutes. Through the use of CATE, the design of intricate three dimensional architecture of scaffold can be realized and these scaffolds can be fabricated with reproducible accuracy to assist biologists in studying complex tissue engineering problems. This thesis reports a research addressing some of the challenges in applying the CATE approach for the biomimetic design and freeform fabrication of tissue scaffolds. The major research accomplishments reported in this thesis include: a) The development of a BioCAD modeling technique for the design and representation of patient specific 3D tissue models based on non-invasive medical image data. b) The development of a biomimetic design approach for design of load bearing tissue scaffold subject to multiple biophysical, geometrical and manufacturing requirements. This includes the design of the unit cell micro-architecture based on tissue morphologies, unit cell characterization and evaluation of the mechanical and transport properties, and the use of unit cells as building block to design anatomic tissue scaffold replacements. c) The development of a CAD based path planning procedure through a direct slicing algorithm which can convert a neutral ISO (International Standards Organization) standardized STEP (Standard for the Exchange of Product Data) formatted NURBS (Non-Uniform Rational B-Spline) geometric representation to a tool path instruction set for layered freeform fabrication. d) The development of a novel Internal Architecture Design (IAD) approach for the mapping of characteristic patterns of the unit cell micro-architectures designed within the 3D scaffold. This design approach is implemented into a process algorithm that converts these 2D patterns to tool path datasets for the 3DPTM (threedimensional printing) and extrusion based freeform fabrication. CATE enables many novel approaches in modeling, design, and fabrication of complex tissue substitutes with enhanced functionality for research in patient specific implant analysis and simulation, image guided surgical planning and scaffold guided tissue engineering. The research will also enable cell biologists and engineers to expand their scope of research and study in the field of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.</span></div>

</ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">Hyperpigmentation is a medical and cosmetic problem caused by an excess accumulation of melanin or the overexpression of the enzyme tyrosinase, leading to several skin disorders, i.e., freckles, melasma, and skin cancer. Tyrosinase is a key enzyme in melanogenesis and thus a target for reducing melanin production. Although abalone is a good source of bioactive peptides that have been used for <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdc61066c","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdc61066c"> several properties including depigmentation, the available information on the anti-tyrosinase property of abalone peptides remains insufficient. This study investigated the anti-tyrosinase properties of Haliotis diversicolor tyrosinase inhibitory peptides (hdTIPs) based on mushroom tyrosinase, cellular tyrosinase, and melanin content assays. The binding conformation between peptides and tyrosinase was also examined by molecular docking and dynamics study. KNN1 showed a high potent inhibitory effect on mushroom tyrosinase with an IC50 of 70.83 μM. Moreover, our selected hdTIPs could inhibit melanin production through the reductions in tyrosinase activity and reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels by enhancing the antioxidative enzymes. RF1 showed the highest activity on both cellular tyrosinase inhibition and ROS reduction. leading to the lower melanin content in B16F10 murine melanoma cells. Accordingly, it can be assumed that our selected peptides exhibited high potential in medical cosmetology applications.</span></div>

After replacement, the wounded limb should be weight bearing and can do flexing or whirling activities with good stability. The necessary prerequisite is that the shape of the artificial knee joint must match human body. It can move coordinately with the surrounding parenchyma only when the shape is accuracy. So the <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdc610d79","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... In this article, the author makes use of three-dimensional laser scanning and computer-aid design technology to scan on the knee joint, and then deal with the output cloud data. Making use of project software Geomagic and Unigraphics to carry out the reconstruction and simulation processing of three-dimensional full-scale mock-up can obtain the very precise knee joint three-dimensional model and the numerical control processing program, which has provided one practical and feasible method for the fast precise designing and digitized manufacturing of individual phantom in clinical medicine.</span></div>
